info.desc: Mark up a command to be entered at an interactive shell.

page.title: Commands

synopsis.code:
mal_inline_cmd = element cmd { mal_attr_link ?, attribute style { xsd:NMTOKENS } ?, attribute mime { text } ?, attribute * - (mal:* | local:*) { text } *,
mal_inline + }

page.p: The cmd element marks a command or a portion of a command run in a shell. It is frequently used to mark the command to run an application. It should not be used to mark the human-readable name of an application; use app for this purpose instead.

The cmd element may be used to mark the entire command, including all arguments. Mallard does not contain elements to mark the arguments specifically, as there is rarely a need to distinguish them. The cmd element may also be used to mark parts of a command, such as options and arguments, when these need to be referenced alone.
The var element may be used inside a cmd element to indicate text that should be replaced by the user.

item.p: The style attribute takes a space-separated list of style hints. Processing tools should adjust their rendering according to those style hints they understand.
The mime attribute takes a valid MIME type. Processing tools may adjust their rendering for particular MIME types.

item.p: The cmd element can link to other pages or documents. See for more information.
The cmd element can have attributes from external namespaces. See for more information on external-namespace attributes on inline elements.

section.title: Comparison to DocBook
section.p: The cmd element is similar to the command element in DocBook. In DocBook, writers frequently use the option element inside command. Mallard does not provide an element for this purpose.
In DocBook, the option element is also used outside the command element. In Mallard, simply use the cmd element for options outside of an entire command.
